evaluation_results.original_answer: In 2022, MA described default interchange fees as a mechanism established by the company or financial institutions to apply when no other settlement terms exist between issuers and acquirers, emphasizing their role in balancing the costs and benefits for all participants in the four-party system. In the 2022 filing the fees were introduced simply as a “default” mechanism to reimburse issuers for costs that enable the network’s value‑exchange. By 2023 the language was expanded to stress that interchange fees “play a key role in balancing the costs and benefits that consumers and merchants derive,” noting that they are collected from acquirers and paid to issuers to offset the services that benefit all participants.  

The 2024 filing deepened this framing: it linked default interchange fees to the broader four‑party fee structure (e.g., the merchant‑discount rate), clarified that the company administers their collection and remittance through the settlement process, and highlighted that the fees help ensure a balanced ecosystem where issuers, acquirers and merchants each receive appropriate compensation for the costs and value created by their participation.
